If our amendment is not accepted, it is for only one reason. Labor has found that such language is not acceptable to some of its factions and the Government cannot live with it. Once again, we shall experience the Prime Minister and his Ministers knowing what is right, but doing what is wrong. No wonder the Australian dollar is falling and our credibility in the world is bottom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating a private member's Bill presented by the Australian Democrats entitled Australian Waters (Nuclear-powered Ships and Nuclear Weapons Prohibition) Bill 1984, the amendment moved by Senator Chaney earlier this afternoon, and a subsequent Government amendment. Inevitably, events in recent weeks in regard to New Zealand's ban on the entry of United States ships to New Zealand ports and the United States' response have provoked general discussion on the relationship of small countries such as Australia and New Zealand with the United States. Just as inevitably, this has raised the question of ANZUS and Australian and New Zealand dependence on the Americans in our defence area.

SPEECH.PARA: I was fascinated to hear Senator Sir John Carrick mention that a 1982 Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence report said that the Committee considered that the ANZUS Treaty provision stated that it gave greater commitment to the defence of Australia than simply consultation. I find that statement fascinating. The ANZUS Treaty itself gives no greater commitment to the defence of this country or of New Zealand by the Americans than is provided by the consultative process. I am fascinated by this also because it perpetuates one of the great myths that have surfaced over recent years on the ANZUS Treaty and America's alliance with other Western nations. The myth is that the United States will help Australia or other allies of America whenever those countries need it and however they need it. History does not substantiate that point of view. It is worth pointing out what any half-hearted student of history will know-namely, that this is not the case. America, in line with its past behaviour, will enter into a conflict in support of any of its allies only when and if it is in America's political, military or economic interests to do so. One does not have to go back far into this century to see that this is correct and the United States has every right to take its own interests into consideration.

I object to the fact that some people, who I am sure are well-meaning but somewhat misguided, refuse to acknowledge that America has the right to take its own interests into account, that it has done so in the past and is likely to do so in the future. In recent times, one has only to look to what Nixon said in 1969 in what has become known as the Guam doctrine, or one can also go back to the two major world wars to ascertain America's attitude to its allies. It came into those wars, in the first case when politically it was in its interests to do so, and in the second case when it was directly attacked. The United States did not support its traditional allies, England and France, over the Suez crisis because it was not in America's economic interest to do so, nor did it support its traditional allies, the Dutch and the Australians, over the Indonesian raid on Western New Guinea. Again, that occurred because such support was not in America's economic interests. It was made clear by the Americans that United States' interests in Indonesia were considered by American officials to be at least as important as their interests in Australia, and economically far more so because of American dependence on the rubber and oil which the Americans could obtain from Indonesia. Notwithstanding the fact that Australian officials pointed to our vulnerability in terms of a takeover of Western New Guinea by Indonesia, the Americans were prepared to take the attitude that they had to sell us on the proposition that there was a greater threat if the communists took Indonesia than if Indonesia took New Guinea, and that the United States would not jeopardise its economic interests in Indonesia for the sake of America's alliance with Australia.
Nixon went further than that in the Guam doctrine in 1969 in which he said:
The United States will keep all its treaty commitments.
That in itself was fine, but the doctrine continued:

We shall provide a shield if a nuclear power threatens the freedom of a nation allied with us or of a nation whose survival we consider vital to our security and the security of the region as a whole.
A report by the United States Secretary of State in 1969-70 said:
In cases involving other types of aggression we--
that is the United States-

shall furnish military and economic assistance when requested and as appropriate. But we shall look to the nation directly threatened to assume the primary responsibility of providing the manpower for its defense.
In other words, the Americans were taking on what they called a more restrained diplomatic style in Asia and the Pacific:

Our new approach calls for a new diplomatic style. We will attempt, consistent with protection of our own interests, to reduce our official presence and visibility abroad. We will emphasise mutuality and multilateralism. We will encourage others to assume a greater share of the responsibilities for the security and economic development of the area.

Nowhere is it said that the United States will automatically leap to the defence of any country in this area unless there is a direct nuclear threat. Nowhere does the United States promise automatically to come to Australia's aid if she is threatened by her northern neighbours. That proves the rightness of what Senator Chipp, then a member of the House of Representatives, said on 22 May 1969 that the ANZUS Treaty, while being 'a precious piece of paper' was only a piece of paper. Without the intent and good faith of one of the signatories to that Treaty-that is, the United States-it is not worth the paper it is written on. Although there is an article in the ANZUS Treaty that says that any member can pull out at any time, the United States in recent weeks has hardly been generous to the small country which took its rights and refused admission to nuclear warships of the United States. Senator Peter Baume said earlier in this debate by way of interjection-and he was joined by others-that he genuinely believed that the United States would leap to our assistance. I respect Senator Baume's point of view. He is entitled to that belief, but I say with the greatest of respect that I think he is deluding himself. The Americans have not behaved that way in the past. There is no reason to believe that they will behave that way in the future. Indeed, I suggest that Australians remember that the United States sat back in two world wars and watched hundreds of thousands of Australians die in the first years of those wars before it deigned to enter itself, and then it did so not as a result of a treaty or an alliance but because it was in its own interests. This is only one of the myths that have been spread about and generally accepted by an easily deluded public over Australia's relationship with the United States.

One other myth which is frequently alluded to in the letters pages of Australia's major newspapers is that anyone who criticises the United States in any way at all is automatically anti-American and, by being anti-American, somehow through some quantum leap, becomes pro-Russian. This is arrant nonsense. If we are to be prevented from criticising anybody at all, I wonder what has happened to Australia's freedom of speech. If we cannot criticise a country without being accused of being totally opposed to that country and in favour of one of its enemies, then I wonder what has happened to the tolerance that is supposed to exist in the Australian democracy. Surely there is no need for us to become or act as if we have become America's fifty-first State to prove that we are not anti-American. Indeed, I suggest that Australia and the Australian Government should not have to prove that we are anything at all except pro-Australian. I believe, although others such as Senator Baume and Senator Sir John Carrick may not believe it, that handing over our land, our facilities and our port facilities to the United States as part of its nuclear global strategy, thereby making us prime targets in any nuclear offensive, is not necessarily being pro-Australian.

We talk about the ANZUS Treaty as if somehow it was produced in a nuclear age-in a massive, global nuclear age. It was not. It is a 1951 treaty, one of something in excess of 120 treaties we have one thing and another with the United States. This 1951 ANZUS Treaty was established in the Japanese threat context and not in a nuclear threat context. Yet, through the Guam doctrine, the Americans have changed the intention of that Treaty somehow, without changing the wording of it, to be relevant only in a nuclear context.

Another myth that wanders around this chamber from time to time, and not just on this matter, is that changing one's stance according to changing circumstances is somehow dishonourable. That may well be the case if the changes are for purely political purposes or are merely pragmatic ones, but the Democrats policy has been anti-nuclear since 1977, since our inception. It is not new. The contents of the legislation before us today are totally consistent with the Democrats policy from the very beginning. Indeed, our attitude to treaties has been one of balance rather than a purely sycophantic one. Our international relations policy makes it quite clear that, as far as the Democrats are concerned, in the review of existing treaties understandings for defence or in any new such treaties we will take as the paramount consideration the security of Australia, regularly weighing any risk to our security through association with super-powers by possible involvement in global conflicts against the protection conferred against attack by lesser forces. The Guam doctrine indicates that there is no help to be expected from the United States in the case of any attack by lesser forces unless that involves nuclear and communistic attack. We all know that the lesser forces north of Australia do not at the moment have those facilities.

We are not changing our minds. Senator Chipp has not changed his mind. His attitude in 1969 indicated quite clearly a belief in a piece of paper being valued only according to the intent and good faith of the signatories and the way in which they intended to operate it. I point out that not only is not changing one's mind often not foolish; it is also frequently vitally necessary. For those honourable senators here who do not recall it, I remind them of the fact that in 1935 the then Mr Menzies returned from a trip to Germany full of praise for Hitler and for the way in which he was governing Germany. The Sydney Morning Herald on 28 October 1935 ran a story quoting Mr Menzies as saying that the nazi leadership was inspiring and as saying to a gathering of old Melbournians: 'I thought it was a great thing for Germany to have arms. If you and I were sitting at our firesides in Berlin we would not be critical of a leadership that had produced such results'. Mr Menzies was forced, quite rightly, completely to re-assess those comments some few years later.

We then have brought forward the argument that being anti-nuclear is exactly the same thing as favouring unilateral disarmament. That is arrant nonsense. The Democrats are not and never have been in favour of unilateral disarmament. We have never asked nor expected the United States to disarm unilaterally. Nobody in his right mind would. What we favour, and what I believe the Australian people deserve, is a strong independent Australia, a country with a defence force which is capable of actually defending us regardless of the form of attack, particularly if the form of attack is non-communistic and non-nuclear, for then, as the Americans themselves have said, we need not expect any help from them. At the moment we have a defence force which is almost totally linked in, as Senator Chipp said, to the nuclear global strategy of the Americans. We have something which is not sufficient to defend Australia against a non-nuclear attack. I suggest we have to stop this silly nonsense of tying ourselves into purchase of defence which is of value only if it is combined with United States weaponry, weaponry which under ANZUS will be used to help us only after consultation and after the full constitutional decision-making processes that operate in the United States are complied with; that is, after full congressional debate. I suggest that, in a nuclear attack, by the time Congress has debated what to do we might just as well forget about it.

For those people who are listening and for those people here who have not read it, I refer to Articles III and IV of the ANZUS Treaty. It is frequently thrown about by people who have not read it. It might be time that some people out there knew what it actually said. Article III states:
The parties will consult together whenever in the opinion of any of them the territorial integrity, political independence or security of any of the parties is threatened in the Pacific.
That is fine. As Senator Chipp said, that merely requires a phone call, probably of condolence. Article IV says:

Each party recognises that an armed attack in the Pacific area on any of the parties would be dangerous to its own peace and safety and declares that it would act to meet the common danger in accordance with its constitutional processes.
Any such armed attack and all measures taken as a result thereof shall be immediately reported to the Security Council of the United Nations.
I repeat:
Any such armed attack and all measures taken as a result thereof . . .
There is no guarantee of them, but if there are any such measures they will be reported to the United Nations Security Council.

Honourable senators will recall that the debate on this Bill began in September 1984, at a time when the New Zealand Government recommitted itself to a policy of prohibiting visits to that country of nuclear powered and/or armed warships of all nations. This was something that Mr Lange reiterated less than a week ago. This is not something which simply is limited to the United States; it is multilateral. It is not an anti-American policy; it is an anti-nuclear one. Events of the past few weeks in our region once again demand that urgent and rational debate take place on the Bill that we have before the Senate today and, as has been said before, on all components of the ANZUS Treaty.

The Australian Democrats are not interested in rhetoric. We are interested in seeing this country genuinely and actively committed to disarmament. If that is to be the case we have to make decisions now. We all know the sorts of things that have been brought before us today. We all know that the two super-powers have between them 50,000 nuclear weapons; that our planet and all life on it can, as Senator Sir John Carrick among others mentioned, be destroyed by nuclear weapons; and that $1m is spent on the arms race every minute of the day while millions of people die from starvation, disease and ill-health. We all know that our priorities are skewed. We all know that the cost of the arms race is increasing, that the numbers of weapons are increasing, that their destructive power is increasing and that people's fear is increasing. This Government states in its Australian Labor Party platform:

Only if ordinary people demonstrate consistently their insistence that this madness be stopped will the world's leaders move to take action to bring it to a halt. For the Australian Labor Government, there can be no higher priority than nuclear arms control and disarmament. If we fail in this, we fail in everything.

The Australian Democrats applaud these statements, but we ask: For how long do the Australian people have to continue to tell this Government that they want no part in the war games of the super-powers and that they do not want to be nuclear targets? When will this Government's pledge be honoured by actions? I would have thought that the Labor Government, as a first step in honouring its pledge to the Australian people, would en masse today support the Australian Democrats' Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fear that this debate on a Bill to prohibit the passage of nuclear powered ships and vessels carrying nuclear weapons through Australian waters or in the airspace over them has taken an unfortunate turn in that it has almost become an occasion for a definitive statement by this Senate on the whole question of the obligations inherent in the Australian-United States of America alliance or relationship. I do not believe that the Australian Waters (Nuclear-powered Ships and Nuclear Weapons Prohibition) Bill ought to be asked to bear that tremendous weight. The fact is that the Australian Labor Party Government, elected by the Australian people twice in the past two years, is a democratically elected government. Australia is a democracy in a world of totalitarian states. We have a natural association or alliance, therefore, with the United States, itself a great democracy. We have expressed that association historically over the decades since the Second World War when the Australian Labor Party forged an alliance with the United States in various ways, including the ANZUS Treaty. But to turn this debate on a Bill concerning the offering of permission to enter our ports to nuclear powered vessels or those which might be carrying nuclear weapons into a debate on the ANZUS alliance, that expression of the relationship-the questions of the bases, the MX missile and the B52 flights have been brought up-seems to me to be going far too far, given the obligation on us as senators in looking at this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to go further than the Minister for Resources and Energy and Minister Assisting the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, did in his dealing with the foreign affairs stance of our Government. My only comment about Senator Haines's speech would be that I think it is too simplistic to say that our only obligation is to be pro-Australian. I believe that that is precisely to fall into the trap that has bedevilled humanity for generation after generation and century after century. It is to retreat into a possible isolationism and certainly a nationalism. It sounds patriotic when expressed, but I believe that our obligation is to a much wider sweep of humanity. We are involved internationally in combating, and in conflict with, totalitarian regimes of the Left and of the Right. I believe that we as Australians, fortunate to live in a democracy, must offer assistance, where we can, to those who may be crushed by these totalitarian forces or who are in alliance with those who are trying to resist them. How that should be undertaken, whether by way of a military alliance or some other means, is, of course, a matter for debate, but I believe that it needs to be kept in mind that alliances with like-minded democracies are an essential expression of an international character of our obligations, given that conflict with totalitarian states which besets us at the moment.

I want to speak in terms of the Bill, which is rather a new note in this debate today. I find that I cannot support it because it has two very fundamental flaws. The first flaw concerns the identification of the use of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes with the use of nuclear energy to develop horrendous weapons of war. I do not believe it aids the debate in Australia at all to associate continuously and identify the use of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes with its use for horrendous destruction. Always to say of uranium that its uses are evil and to be resisted is to invest it with some sort of demonic quality which I think in the end involves an abdication of our free will as human beings as to how it should be utilised for mankind. My father quoted from Shakespeare now and again when we did something wrong. He would say:
The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars, but in ourselves, that we are underlings.

The fault lies in humanity, in the misuse and abuse of nuclear energy for destructive purposes, and not in the inherent qualities of uranium itself. To bundle all the possible uses of uranium together and categorise them all as demonic and to be resisted is, I think, to be guilty of a confusion which does not help the debate.

We find in this Bill an attempt to prohibit not merely the passage of vessels carrying nuclear weapons but the passage of nuclear powered ships. As I say, I think the identification of the two is absurd and probably comes about because of equating nuclear powered ships with naval vessels bearing nuclear weapons. Of course, that is not the case.

I was interested at the weekend to hear a radio item about an icebreaker of the Russian fleet liberating many hundreds of whales that were trapped in an ice blocked fiord in the Soviet Union. As I have discovered, that icebreaker was diesel powered. However, it is well known that the Russians have nuclear powered icebreakers. I would have thought that a good sensible use of nuclear propulsion would be the use of a nuclear powered icebreaker to bash ice aside and liberate whales from certain death. Perhaps people who have 'save the whale' stickers on their bumper bars would agree. Surely they would not advocate the inclusion in small print of the words 'but not by nuclear propelled icebreakers'.

It seems to me wrong continuously to confuse and identify the two uses that can be made of nuclear power. The fact is that on some previous occasions people who say that there is an absolute identity between the two uses have likened those in the Australian Labor Party and Australian society generally who see a difference as somehow the moral equivalent to opium or heroin pushers. We have been called that in this chamber. I find that analogy quite wrong. Opium poppies are grown in my area of north-west Tasmania. In fact, we have just harvested a crop of many acres. The hills are covered by that mauve coloured poppy. The choice is one of making use of the product of opium poppies to alleviate the suffering of pain of mankind or allowing it to find its way into the back alleys of Sydney or Melbourne to be administered with dirty needles and cause misery and destruction of human life. There is a choice in the use of heroin between life and death. I believe there is a choice in the use of uranium between life and death. The fact is that nuclear powered or propelled vessels are probably a good use of that source of energy.

The fact is that the Australian Democrats have been moving to a more considerate and reasonable stand. I assure Senator Chipp that I do not say this in a patronising way but I believe there was a movement last year in the realisation of the Democrats that good uses can be made of nuclear energy. One recalls that, during the debate on the Customs (Prohibition of Importation of Nuclear Hardware) Bill, the Democrats made a concession in their attitude to an earlier draft of the Bill and recognised that the use of imported nuclear hardware to help produce medical and industrial isotopes at Lucas Heights was of benefit in alleviating the suffering of patients and of benefit generally in terms of the industrial uses that were outlined in that debate. They made an exception. In other words, there are good uses of nuclear energy. I believe that that ought to have been recognised in the redraft of this Bill over the summer months and the parliamentary recess. Allowance should have been made for the fact that nuclear propelled vessels represent a use of this source of energy that can be beneficial to mankind. Of course, as with the Lucas Heights reactor, there would have to be the most stringent and careful safeguards surrounding the operation of nuclear powered vessels if they were in Australian ports. I do not think anyone in this chamber would be opposed to the most stringent regulation being applied to the use of that energy source.

Not only should the Democrats rethink the identification of these two quite different questions, which is apparently the basis of their Bill, but they should also have a look at the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, which, organised at it is in the international community, is the only hope of mankind to try to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons. The Treaty comes up for renegotiation and reaffirmation this year. One finds in the Treaty, to which the Australian Government has given considerable resources in trying to attract continued adherence by the member parties to its terms, a recognition of the very tension which lies at the heart of the debate in Australia. What this Bill totally ignores is the resolution of the conflict, if it be a conflict, in the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. One finds in Article II, which concerns the obligations of non-nuclear weapons states, that a member party 'undertakes not to receive a transfer from any transferor whatsoever of nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices or of control over such weapons or explosive devices directly, or indirectly' and so on. However, Article IV (1) of the Treaty states:

Nothing in this Treaty shall be interpreted as affecting the inalienable right of the Parties to the Treaty to develop research, production and use of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes without discrimination and in conformity with articles I and II of this Treaty.

In other words, one finds there the very tension and conflict which, as I say, are a characteristic of the Australian debate. It offers immunity in advance for illegal and violent activity in achieving what might be a good and desirable end.

Either Senator Haines was overcome in the Democrat Party room when she raised this matter or the drafters of the Bill have not seen fit to take into account this unbelievable clause which goes back to medieval times when the king of England said that, by virtue of his feudal position, he could not be subjected to the courts. The fact is that under this Bill the Government will be allowed to don feudal garb and to give to itself and its officers immunity in a way which I believe should not be supported by this chamber. TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting I was pointing out that there were two flaws in the Bill which has been presented by the Democrats concerning the prohibition of visits by nuclear powered vessels or vessels thought to be carrying nuclear arms into Australian waters. The two flaws were, firstly, that the Bill, wrongly in my submission, identifies and confuses the peaceful uses of nuclear energy, in this instance for propulsion of a vessel through water, with the use of nuclear energy for horrendous destructive purposes in those armaments which, in the arsenals of the super-powers, threaten the very history of mankind.

SPEECH.PARA: It seemed to me that insofar as the Bill refuses to make any concessions to the logical and practical distinction between those two uses of nuclear energy, it could not be supported. I likened the responsibility which faces mankind in the use of uranium to that which faces us in Tasmania, for example, with the use of opium poppies in that they can be used either to enhance human life and alleviate suffering and pain or they can find their way into the back alleys of Kings Cross or St Kilda where, with the use of dirty needles, the addicts are brought to ultimate destruction. In other words, it is the destruction of life rather than the enhancing of life. I pointed out that the Democrats, over the previous 18 months, have conceded, by way of subsequent drafts of legislation, that uranium and the energy derived from it can have useful beneficial purposes for mankind. I instanced the use of medical and industrial isotopes. Senator Chipp's amended Bill of late last year conceded that the use of such isotopes was beneficial.

I pointed out that there was another flaw to this Bill in which those who do not agree with my previous argument could nevertheless find sufficient reason for not supporting the Bill in its present form. Quite extraordinarily, this Bill represents a most serious erosion of principles which we normally hold very dear in our common law and parliamentary system. In the book on administrative law by Professor Wade, which is the great text-book in our English tradition of law, under the heading 'Legal status of the Crown' it is stated:

It is fundamental to the rule of law that the Crown, like other public authorities, should bear its fair share of legal liability and be answerable for wrongs done to its subjects. The immense expansion of governmental activity from the latter part of the nineteenth century onwards made it intolerable for the government, in the name of the Crown, to enjoy exemption from the ordinary law.
Indeed, it is not a modern matter. The Bill of Rights itself provides:
That the pretended power of dispensing with laws, or the execution of laws by regal authority, as it hath been assumed and exercised of late, is illegal.
Very briefly what that means is that the granting of legal immunity to the Crown or its officials is something which is abhorred by our legal system. Yet clause 6 of the Bill states:

The Minister may, by instrument signed by him, direct the taking of such action, including the use of force, as is in his opinion necessary to be taken for the purpose of the performance of the duty imposed on the Government of the Commonwealth by sub-section (1).
The clause continues:
Action taken by a person under and in accordance with an instrument under sub-section (2) shall for all purposes be deemed to have been lawfully taken by the person.
It further continues:

An action does not lie against the Commonwealth, the Minister or any other person for loss or damage suffered by a person in consequence of action that is, by virtue of sub-section (2), to be deemed to have been lawfully taken.

So we see there that legal immunity is granted in advance to officers of the Government or those acting by virtue of the authority of the Minister, for actions which may be illegal and violent. I recall that one of the worst features of the situation in Rhodesia under the unilateral declaration of independence was that the then Government gave to its army, on its sweeps through the countryside, immunity in advance. In other words, whatever the army did by way of rape, murder or pillage, it knew that it would not face legal consequences. One can imagine what sort of action that led to. It is not the case that we are looking at such an extreme situation-I have no doubt that the Democrats would not have in mind such an extreme situation-but the fact is that that is the way in which they have chosen to draft their Bill in its operative clause and, to me, it renders the whole of the Bill obnoxious.

It is not as though the Democrats have not had notice of the view of the relevant Senate committee as to the way in which the clause should be viewed. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, in October 1984-that is some four or five months ago-drew the attention of this chamber to the clause. It said, in the language of the Committee-honourable senators know that we do not say things definitively; we point them out and make the chamber aware of the possibility of a conflict with our traditional liberty-that there was a conflict. Honourable senators have been alerted over many months to that conflict with our traditional concept of rights and liberties of the subject. I for one find it amazing that the clause should remain after that intervening period. Not a jot, not a tittle of that offending and offensive clause, has been altered.

It seems to me to be ironic and worth noting that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee largely came into existence because of a common conviction of Senator Alan Missen and me that previous legislation of former conservative coalition governments which had regulated the uranium industry in Australia was marred by sections which could only make any sense within the Cold War context when uranium from Rum Jungle was supplied to our allies in the 1950s. The fact that those clauses in the then legislation regulating the uranium industry were continued in subsequent reaffirmations by this Parliament was something of concern to both Senator Alan Missen and me. It was one of the factors which led to our support for the setting up of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. As I say, it is ironic that this Bill should offend in the way that it does. The Democrats should heed the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. They should heed the voice of one of their own senators, Senator Haines, who was a member of that Committee. I do not believe her voice can be suppressed for very long in an appropriate forum.

They did not succeed, of course, and successive generations have seen that man cannot and will not succeed in his bid to eradicate armaments or the need for armaments.

Today in a society that is primed to a world of increasing tension there are two camps-one seeking unilateral disarmament, and the other seeking multilateral disarmament. Whilst the latter principle is based on the policy of arms control by negotiation on a one to one basis, the former principle, to which Senator Chipp and the Democrats subscribe, advocates the complete laying down of arms by individuals nations. Unilateral disarmament includes also the revoking of any treaties, and in Australia's case this, of course, would have to mean ANZUS. Unilateral disarmament is, at best, a questionable goal. Costa Rica is the only nation I can recall to have attempted such methods of arms control. A series of military coups in this Latin American country led to the abolition of armed forces. Now, instead of instituting a state of beauteous tranquillity and Shangri-la revisited, a state of internal turmoil has unfortunately ensued. Of course, Costa Rica now finds its territories being used as operating bases by people waging guerrilla wars against Nicaragua.

As for multilateral arms control-this is a problem that presents itself today-it is imperative, if negotiations are to succeed, that all parties participating in a treaty recognise their similar interests, recognise that the control of the buildup of arms will serve those interests and recognise also that they must trust their negotiating partners. ANZUS not only provides Australia with formal agreements and formal opportunities to persuade a great ally, America, to follow those directions which we would prefer, it also provides us with far improved informal contacts with the administrative forces of America.

When the links with the United States are severed, the right to voice protest or support for moves initiated by this vital ally will be silenced. India serves to exemplify this, leading, as it does, the group of non-aligned nations. The United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics tend to discount virtually everything India has to say. India, in its bid for non-aligned status, has forgone its capacity to influence policies of arms control. Let us face facts: India is a major nation and it could have far more influence if it decided it wanted to, rather than just sit on the non-aligned fence. With ANZUS Australia at least maintains its right and ability to intercede.

When the Democrats advocate unilateral disarmament the natural presumption is that they are advocating that Australia undertake non-aligned status. A revoking of the ANZUS Treaty or any refusal to co-operate with the United States in its nuclear policies could be seen as a condemnation of its policies. Australia would then become a non-aligned nation. But becoming non-aligned does not come cheaply. I recall when this issue first blew up. In a recent State by-election campaign in my town of Rockhampton the new member for Capricornia, Keith Wright, went public in the Press, saying that he believed that Australia should become non-aligned and neutral and that when he got to the party room he would be seeing to it that that sort of thing happened. I am not quite sure what has happened and what his contribution has been within the confines of that party room.

Let us look at Switzerland. In Switzerland 21.3 per cent of the national budget is spent on defence. In Australia only 9.1 per cent is spent on defence. Whilst in Australia we have a paid professional and civilian armed contingent whose members can choose to serve for a minimum of three years and after that sign on again for another three years, in Switzerland every fit male is conscripted into regular, unpaid military training from the time he is 19 years old. This training continues until he is 60 years of age. This non-aligned nation is so primed to respond to war that within 48 hours 400,000 men can be called into action. Sweden also is a non-aligned or neutral country. It has more men under arms than we have. It has been estimated that to attain the same level of defence preparedness as Sweden now has we would have to expend $1.3 billion more per annum than we are already spending on our defence preparedness. So non-alignment or neutrality does not come cheaply.

Therefore, one has to look at what one could do in this instance. We are but a small nation and I suppose that to get the best value for our dollar we must recognise that we have to have alliances and we have to team up with out friends. If we do not do it from a position of strength but rather from a position of weakness I submit that we do not negotiate; we just succumb. To us ANZUS is part of that strength.

As well as being part of ANZUS we have the technology transfers that are available to us. We could not afford to do the massive amount of research and development that unfortunately go into the weapons systems and the means of delivery in the world today. We can take part in joint exercises. We can keep our armed forces, small though they might be, at peak strength and peak readiness because we can exercise with other nations. We can bring our troops up to standard because we are exercising in fields in which we would not exercise by ourselves. We can exercise our naval forces with nuclear submarines. We can exercise in over-shore activities and so on down the line. So we can operate at very much reduced expense and keep our troops in a great state of readiness.

In the year 4 BC a Roman writer by the name of Vegetius wrote: 'Let him who desires peace, prepare for war'. I think those words are as true today as they were then.
